build-tools/build-docker-images/loci/pat.message:
Lets try to make it a bit more generic. Instead of this being a boolean, allow it to be a list of package requirements. Ie:

PIP_UPGRADE="pip>=22.2.0 some_other_package<3.0"

If not empty, run "pip install --upgrade $PIP_UPGRADE"
I would create a completely separate script, "upgrade_pip_packages.sh" and add one call to it in the top-level script.

I like this approach.

One thing that I found out is that every environment variable that starts with the prefix "PIP_" is automatically consumed by the tool (https://pip.pypa.io/en/stable/topics/configuration/#environment-variables). So when I tried to experiment with the example you provided, I ended up having some issues with it, because "PIP_UPGRADE" already expects a boolean value in it (what a coincidence):

> "pip>=22.2.0 is not a valid value for upgrade option, please specify a boolean value like yes/no, true/false or 1/0 instead."

So I had to change the environment variable name to UPGRADE_PIP_PACKAGES.

Also, it's worth mentioning that, while testing, I noticed that LOCI calls the pip_install.sh script a few times during the building process (first passing bindep as an argument, then some packages, etc).

Consequently, the `pip install --upgrade $UPGRADE_PIP_PACKAGES` is being executed a few times as well, although it only effectively upgrades/downgrades the packages on the first execution. After the first execution, we get:

> "Requirement already satisfied: ..."

In this case, should I unset the environment variable after the first execution?
If you think that there's another approach worth exploring, let me know and I'll give it a try.

Done.

Added a call to the pip upgrade script right before the final pip install.

any comment on what this does?
Ack

From Dbus documentation - The mode needs to be one of replace, fail, isolate, ignore-dependencies, ignore-requirements. If "replace" the call will start the unit and its dependencies, possibly replacing already queued jobs that conflict with this. If "fail" the call will start the unit and its dependencies, but will fail if this would change an already queued job. If "isolate" the call will start the unit in question and terminate all units that aren't dependencies of it. If "ignore-dependencies" it will start a unit but ignore all its dependencies. If "ignore-requirements" it will start a unit but only ignore the requirement dependencies.

So we chose replace as the best option.

Right, this is not the correct way of implementing this feature. This patch is preventing the compute node from loading the OVS trunk extension. But the problem is in the compute node configuration: the service_plugin list is empty (not defined):
Dec 05 17:53:35.903922 ubuntu-jammy-inmotion-iad3-0032415088 neutron-openvswitch-agent[26931]: DEBUG neutron.plugins.ml2.drivers.openvswitch.agent.ovs_neutron_agent [-] service_plugins                = [] {{(pid=26931) log_opt_values /usr/local/lib/python3.10/dist-packages/oslo_config/cfg.py:2602}}


The question here is if we should enforce the definition of the service_plugins in a compute node. This is the perfect example of what could happen in an environment if upgraded with this patch; if the compute node doesn't have the service_plugins list with "trunk" populated, the trunk extension in OVS won't be loaded.

> Patch Set 3: Code-Review-1

> This has some serious implications about pipeline processing.  Have you traced through all of the possibilities?

The only place where I'm finding executeJobs() being used is in _processOneItem() to determine whether to set changed=T/F - subsequent to that it doesn't appear to alter the immediate control flow (changed is only further modified or returned)

_processOneItem() appears to be only used in processQueue() and the return value alters 'queue_changed', which appears to have some impact on debug logging and and cause the return value of processQueue() to return T/F

processQueue()'s return value appears impact whether or not the while-loop in Scheduler#_process_pipeline() (scheduler.py) continues or exits

service-mgmt/sm-db/database/create_sm_db.message: It increases the max failures to 10 and interval to 90, this results service failure not to be correct for up to 900 seconds. That is a very long time to recover a failed service. We have to consider all different scenarios.

Got it.

We noticed that the previously configured values were inconsistent, because while mgr-restful-lugin waited 30 seconds for ceph-mgr, SM only waited 15 seconds for mgr-restful-plugin. That is, the SM is not waiting the required timeout defined in the mgr-restful-plugin.

As we cannot use the same timeout as before, for the reason explained above, what we can do is decrease the number of retries, so that it does not wait so long.

So we will have a maximum time of 450 seconds.

should we set defaults to minimum recommended value of 43 ?

My thoughts were that it might make it harder to diagnose the problem. If we set a non-zero default then with a low number of routers, most users won't have an issue. If those users then increase the number of routers then outages might start to occur for seemingly no reason. I decided that it would be more clear if there was consistent behaviour before the user chooses to add the delay.

/PATCHSET_LEVEL.message: Hi, Luiz! Could you please rebase this change?

Thank you for working on this Luiz. There are a few concerns:

1) I like that we're bumping up the microversion - we should do that, but, we cannot allow a security loophole by enforcing policy only on newer microversions. Remember that the microversion is specified in a user's request -- so they can easily use an older microversion to get access to these fields. 

2) I think we can bump up the API microversion, but, write a release note indicating that the API version bump is just informational -- i.e., regardless of the actual version of the API request, these fields will be available only if policy allows it - otherwise, they can still see the fields, but their values will be set to None

3) As noted inline, i think we should not override the context.is_admin check. We should introduce a brand new policy and make that policy default to "rule:admin". 

I'll be happy to clarify these points.

Can you also add a "DocImpact" to your Commit message - i think we need to update the API reference to capture these changes.

I agree with the change, and understand why you need this.

However I'm concerned with the current commit message because it mentions several items specific to RDO and its CI and looks very confusing from view point of Puppet OpenStack's CI.

Please find my inline comments and consider removing items very specific to RDO, and "generalize" what is explained in the commit message.

Note that currently, when we enable puppet modules RPM, we install puppet modules both with RPM and from sources. Puppet modules from RPM goes in "/usr/share/openstack-puppet/modules", and modules from source goes in /etc/puppet/modules [1]. But as the RPM module dir is first in modulepath [2] ("earlier directories having priority over later ones" [3]) we use RPM ones.

[1] https://github.com/rdo-infra/ansible-role-weirdo-puppet-openstack/blob/4d676307eb52fc33ea8562f57c4d6028ffe1cd02/tasks/main.yml#L121
[2] https://github.com/rdo-infra/ansible-role-weirdo-puppet-openstack/blob/4d676307eb52fc33ea8562f57c4d6028ffe1cd02/defaults/main.yml#L54
[3] https://puppet.com/docs/puppet/5.5/dirs_modulepath.html

raise Exception('This test uses methods that set internal oslo_db '
    Exception: This test uses methods that set internal oslo_db state, but it does not claim to use the database. This will conflict with the setup of tests that do use the database and cause failures later.
    

Captured pythonlogging:
~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~
    2022-11-24 06:27:38,529 INFO [nova.virt.driver] Loading compute driver 'fake.SmallFakeDriver'

This test runs without any DB so every call that would go the the DB is poisioned to stop the test cleanly. 

File "/home/zuul/src/opendev.org/openstack/nova/nova/objects/instance.py", line 969, in _load_migration_context
    self._context, self.uuid))
  File "/home/zuul/src/opendev.org/openstack/nova/.tox/py37/lib/python3.7/site-packages/oslo_versionedobjects/base.py", line 184, in wrapper
    result = fn(cls, context, *args, **kwargs)
  File "/home/zuul/src/opendev.org/openstack/nova/nova/objects/migration_context.py", line 85, in get_by_instance_uuid
    context, instance_uuid, columns=['migration_context'])
  File "/home/zuul/src/opendev.org/openstack/nova/nova/db/api.py", line 969, in instance_extra_get_by_instance_uuid
  
This part of the stack trace shows that the code tries to load migration_context from the DB. Nova has this lazy loading behavior where if a field of an object is not defined when it is accessed then nova tries to load it from the DB. In this test you don't have DB to load from, so you need to make sure that the instance object has the migration_context field defined. In ussuri, the fake_instance.fake_instance_obj() call returns an instance that has the migration_context field defined, in train it does not. This is why your test fails.

I suggest to add
  inst.migration_context = None
to fake_instance.fake_instance_obj the same way is that function has it in ussuri. That will make your test pass.
ok so this is the main delta to make the test pass.

tripleo_ansible/roles/tripleo_cephadm/te.message:
Still:

1. Not sure about the var name (as it's not defined in tht yet)
2. Do we need additional variables for manila?

@Giulio @Goutham @Victoria, it would be great having your input here: This file is the output of deployed Ceph, which means here we can collect all the info related to the deployed ceph-nfs.
I think we need to have the VIP information that should be used by Manila/new driver, but I'm wondering if we don't actually have to rely on the TripleO info because, as long as the driver as ceph.conf info, it can:

1. connect to the cluster and run the "ceph orch ps" command
2. parse the output to get the VIP assigned to the Ingress daemon
3. build the config using that information

I'm asking because we can take TripleO out of the picture in this specific case:

1. we don't need to make extra changes in TripleO in case the VIP changes and the Heat information is not consistent anymore

2. The Ceph cluster can be the source of truth and we don't have to maintain these info aligned in the deployer

What do you think? Any strong opinion on this aspect?

It seems that this modification is causing a issue related to the concurrence of the pid libvirt related files.

2023-01-02T16:20:09.521 1423124: info : libvirt version: 7.0.0, package: 3.stx.2 (STX Builder <stx.builder@opendev.org> Tue, 20 Dec 2022 19:34:09 +0000)
2023-01-02T16:20:09.521 1423124: info : hostname: controller-0
2023-01-02T16:20:09.521 1423124: error : virPidFileAcquirePath:367 : Failed to acquire pid file '/run/libvirtd.pid': Resource temporarily unavailable 

What I think it happens is that one of the virtualization packages added in this review is activating libvirt by default in the host and when the libvirt pod created by stx-openstack launches it tries to relaunch the libvirt service, causing the issue.

A manual solution that works is to rename all pid files (see http://www.dark-hamster.com/server/failed-acquire-pid-file-varrunlibvirtd-pid-resource-temporarily-unavailable/). I believe that to merge this review we need first to understand away to add the packages but not activate libvirt by default and let the libvirt pod in the stx-openstack deals with the activation.

Thanks for looking into it Falcao!
We can investigate it further before including the packages.

Great job Luan!

Just to give a little more context on this change:

> As I wrote in the commit message, LOCI - by default - always creates a user/group with UID/GID 42424 for the project in question.
> 
> If we take stx-horizon as an example, it will create a user/group named "horizon" with UID/GID 42424.
> 
> However, due to the patch mentioned in the commit message, the Debian base image already comes with a user/group with that same UID/GID: "keystone".
> 
> For the vast majority of images, this is not a problem. However, for images that make use of WSGI - such as stx-horizon - this conflict caused the containers to not run correctly. 
> 
> In short, the containers spawns WSGI daemon processes that perform some operations based on the user/group specified in the configuration files (e.g. user/group "horizon"). In one of these operations, they try to change the working directory to the specified user's home directory.
> 
> However, due to the UID/GID conflict, those daemon processes were getting lost because they were capturing, erroneously, the "keystone" user's home directory (instead of "horizon" user's):
> 
> `(2)No such file or directory: mod_wsgi (pid=162): Unable to change working directory to home directory '/var/lib/keystone' for uid=42424.`
> 
> Thus, in order to allow stx-horizon (and other images) to be created with a different UID/GID, this change proposes that PROJECT_UID and PROJECT_GID parameters be used within container building recipes to set different values when needed.

I would not recommend to end users to disable ssl verification in a production setup. at least put a warning in the text, but from a 2022 point of view we should imho not provide c&p code to disable security settings, even with warnings attached.

people tend to ignore the warnings, copy the insecure settings anyway and then get owned.

thus example code in documentation should always be secure to use, see here for more reasoning:

https://www.ftc.gov/about-ftc/bureaus-offices/bureau-consumer-protection/office-technology-research-investigation/guiding-to-safety-how-technical-documentation-writers-can-encourage-software-security

/PATCHSET_LEVEL.message: I'm still not sure whether this is actually a direction worth pursuing...

This seems interesting to me!  I guess once we decide we can't depend on upstream CPython to own our http parser anymore it seems weird to NOT at least TRY and make it more reasonable.  And now that I'm looking at it, the existing py2/py3 MessageClass split is pretty nuts!

I hear https://github.com/MagicStack/httptools is pretty fast (but maybe lacks PROXY support https://github.com/MagicStack/httptools/issues/61) and https://github.com/python-hyper/h11 claims to be very compliant.  Maybe we could steal code/tests or even add something (different/better?) as a dependency!

swift/common/http_protocol.py.message: ok, i forgot about this - this is gross/weird

I maintain it was better than it used to be: https://review.opendev.org/c/openstack/swift/+/640552

But I much prefer the type property we've got above, now.
our new headers object has no "get_payload" method
Nor does it need one. We're the only folks crazy enough to go poking at that as an HTTP server, at least that I'm aware of.

so following the bug, this is like special py3-only "crazy-utf8' headers handling

I assume the new impl just "does the right thing" in all cases?

Did you lift the parser from anywhere specific, like https://github.com/benoitc/http-parser/blob/master/http_parser/pyparser.py#L327 (that project has a cython-impl too)

Yup; old way abused an email parser into parsing HTTP headers. Apparently some emails wouldn't have a nice, bright boundary between headers and subject/body, so there'd need to be some heuristic such that if a header couldn't be parsed, it was assumed that the rest was body. Somewhere in the py3 history, header parsing got more rigid, to the point that legit swift headers (quietly) break things.

HTTP *does* have a bright boundary between headers and body, so parse all headers and ensure that if there's a failure, it causes a 4xx.
I'm surprised there's no base class, the "MessageClass" abstraction seemed to persist across py2=>py3 - is that interface defined somewhere?  How do I know this is a complete implementation?

IDK that I'd call it an "abstraction" exactly -- it's a property of the BaseHTTPRequestHandler. See

- https://github.com/python/cpython/blob/v2.7.18/Lib/BaseHTTPServer.py#L518
- https://github.com/python/cpython/blob/v3.11.0/Lib/http/server.py#L623

From those definitions, the inheritance chains diverge between py2/py3, but they're always rooted in email -- which seems fundamentally wrong.
Where do you want to use this?

It's used down in eventlet: https://github.com/eventlet/eventlet/blob/master/eventlet/wsgi.py#L716-L723

That's also where eventlet sets env['headers_raw'], so I don't think we can normalize headers in __init__() or parse(), sorry. I should add some comments about it, though.
I think storing keys in a uniform way would avoid an explicit loop.
And look at this, you already rely on keys being lower-cased.
Why not lovercase the header key here?
this exception seems new - is this "just" for un-expected parsing errors - or did we move some existing 400 handling into a ValueError?

Yeah, just the errors you see up in parse()

Really, raising HTTPException and LineTooLong are just weird/bad hacks anyway -- longer term, I'd want to rewrite all these except blocks to be one, and hang status codes etc. off hte exception raised.

swift/common/middleware/account_quotas.p.message:
I'm concerned about doing this as a simple read() -- the server will buffer the whole request body before discarding it. If a client started a thousand 5GB uploads *expecting* them to all get too-large responses, it would almost certainly cause out-of-memory kills and be a DoS vector.

If we pursue this in Swift, we'll want to do something more like

 while request.environ['wsgi.input'].read(1 << 16):
      pass  # drop it on the floor

If you're already carrying the patch, I expect you'll want something similar. Might also need to worry about container quotas, or clients trying to upload >5GB.

Hi Tushar

The K8S charms are a little different to others as they only get deployed with a fixed Python version, which is the default Python 3 that's installed with whatever base the charm container is running with (defined in the charmcraft.yaml file).

Across the k8s charms this is currently 20.04 which ships with Python 3.8 so it only really makes sense to test with that version.
Switching to zed will move the unit testing to py3.10 which is not what we want at this point in time.

@Tushar

Appreciate the effort your are putting into pushing the zuul configuration for charmed operators for OpenStack forward.

The runtime for a K8S charm is determined by the container in which the charm code executes - in this case it is still 20.04 which implies Python 3.8 (not 3.10) - you can check this in the metadata.yaml file in the root of each charm repo.

Skip decorators are used to skip a whole test. When the condition is true, the test stops running and returns verdict=SKIPPED

If I'm not mistaken, we don't want to skip tests like test_resources_health [1] when an external load balancer is used. What we want is to NOT executed vips_resource_healthy and ha_proxy_cinder_healthy functions, right?

Instead of a decorator, you can add something like this at the beginning of those functions:
```
if CONF.tobiko.tripleo.has_external_load_balancer:
    LOG.info("external load balancer used - we can skip function blablabla")
    return True
```

instead of adding _new, add a doc string below calling out that this behavior debuted in version 2.74..
Done
method was recently renamed
Done

by using the admin client, it feels like you're missig testing for a scenario - 

this should be shares_v2_client - i.e., a user with a non-privleged role (by default any user with a non-reader role, belonging to the project owning the share)  must be able to create an access rule on a share when its replica is in "error" state. if such a user can do it, then users with an admin role surely can, and we don't need to test that - it's just role hierarchy.
again, why "admin" role - in general avoid testing with admin what you really want to test with the default member's role..

The failure occurs at line 374 -- an ordinary user cannot reset the replica's status by the virtue of default RBAC. So, it makes sense for that call to be made with the admin_client. 

I agree the current code could have used the regular user client (self.shares_v2_client) to make the "create_access_rule" call - feel free to fix it in this patch... 

Does my explanation above (https://review.opendev.org/c/openstack/manila-tempest-plugin/+/865603/comments/d7e563c6_23448090) make sense wrt the testing philosophy here?

I see earlier test failed for the same reason - https://zuul.opendev.org/t/openstack/build/98b1a1539efa46e3a6b87e389213cbb3

existing code is using admin only, https://github.com/openstack/manila-tempest-plugin/blob/master/manila_tempest_tests/tests/api/test_replication_negative.py#L204
if we support add access rule after 2.74, so test will not be negative test, we'd better move this test to test/api/test_replication.py.
Done

We seldom delete tests; the changing API behavior is being microversioned. Perhaps use version "2.73" in the API request for 203-205 instead of deleting this test case. 

If "2.73" isn't supported by tempest configuration (or manila's API in the cloud being tested), you can default to "2.11" (_MIN_SUPPORTED_MICROVERSION, line 30)
Done

this test is no longer a NEGATIVE test (test tag on the line above) with version 2.74... Did you mean "2.73"? If not, with "2.74" it is a duplicate of the "test_add_access_rule_share_replica_error_status_new" test you'r introducing. 


You can fix this by replacing "2.74" with "2.73" in the DDT input --- it is always good practice to test micro-versioned API changes. The idea is testing whether the behavior that's changing in the newer version stays unchanged in the older version.

I suggest also adding a docstring below calling out that with/after version 2.74, you can now add rules even when replicas are in "error" state.
Done

else?

As i suggest above, removing 2.74 from this test makes sense. You should make the "create_access_rule" request with a specific microversion that's the input to this test..
Done

As there is no else condition, I believe there is no need to run this test if microversion is 2.74 or higher, otherwise at the end it will be a test that will create a share replica and reset the status of the share replica, and the cleanup will occur right after. So my suggestion is: at the beginning of the test, skip it if the microversion is >= 2.74. I think there's a decorator for that too :)

Missed the DDT of the test, but I think my comment could still be valid. This if statement might be invalid, considering that you are explicitly tagging the version on the ddt and sending it in the request - As 2.74 would never be the case, you might only drop this if statement?
I understand your point and I'm okay if we want to leave it as is, unless someone else has the same concern or something else requires a new PS to be uploaded.

You have two scenarios, 2.11 and 2.73. As it is `utils.is_microversion_lt(version, '2.74'):` will *never* be false. The if is there only for adding one more step for interpretation, nothing else. If the intention is showing the person reading the code that it should not be that behavior for 2.74, IMHO the best way to signalize would be through a code comment, not an extra if statement. We have several tests like this in the code base, i.e. [1].


[1] https://github.com/openstack/manila-tempest-plugin/blob/master/manila_tempest_tests/tests/api/admin/test_share_types_extra_specs_negative.py#L332-L335
Even if ddt data is passing 2.73, the version parameter makes sense only if its validated/checked inside function definition. so if check should be there.

ansible/roles/kolla-ansible/library/koll.message:
if module.params['vault_addr']

Think you can remove the second part of the conditional. If `module.params['vault_addr'] `  evaluates to true, then vault_addr can not be ''.

I was worried someone might hose their system with different passwords, but thinking about it again, you can always set `kolla_ansible_vault_addr` in the yaml config instead of using an environment variable. That would prevent this issue.

Just checking vault_addr does have the potential to silently fallback to use the file based password generation. The issue is that you may forget to set the environment variable: `KAYOBE_VAULT_ADDR` and then kayobe will generate you a new set of passwords and potentially redeploy the services using these instead of the values in the vault. I wonder if we need a flag to explicitly enable the vault integration?

> Think you can remove the second part of the conditional. If `module.params['vault_addr'] `  evaluates to true, then vault_addr can not be ''.

Good point. I'll remove 👍

> Just checking vault_addr does have the potential to silently fallback to use the file based password generation. The issue is that you may forget to set the environment variable: `KAYOBE_VAULT_ADDR` and then kayobe will generate you a new set of passwords and potentially redeploy the services using these instead of the values in the vault. I wonder if we need a flag to explicitly enable the vault integration?

Yeh if the env var is missing then it will still run because the file is put into etc/kolla for you in previous runs, but obviously if it was the first time running then you would have to have a copy of that file in etc/kolla/passwords.yml that you previously pulled from Vault otherwise Kayobe will go and generate you some. This is how it is at the moment so nothing is changing and also without that logic you wouldn't be able to bootstrap new environments.

I'm not sure I share the same enthusiasm for more options - if the user forgets to set KAYOBE_VAULT_ADDR they're not going to remember to set one to enable the integration either. It also makes it a little clunky IMO. I just see Vault as an additional backend for Kolla passwords so it shouldn't need anything special other than a few params to connect to Vault.

When using this code path, we end up calling genpwd again on line 210. This is not necessarily an issue if it keeps the logic clean, as running genpwd a second time will essentially be a no-op. It does mean we parse the file for a second time, but I don't think this particularly expensive.

The logic is as follows:

- Create a tempfile containing the existing values in etc/kolla/passwords.yml
- kolla_readpwd - Read values that exist in Vault
- kolla_mergepwd - Merge the two files
- kolla_genpwd - Generate any missing values (keys may have been added)
- kolla_writepwd - Write the passwords back into Vault to add the missing values

So the additional genpwd is needed to catch edge cases where a new key is added to the passwords file that needs a value generating.

Was there a particular reason for not uploading the custom passwords? I can see the potential for confusion if someone is using a custom password to override an entry in kolla passwords e.g libvirt_sasl_password. I think we'd end up uploading ` libvirt_sasl_password` with a password that we essentially never use (as this value gets overridden by the custom password but never uploaded).
That's a really good catch I hadn't tested that edge case. I will update this in my latest patch to write back the changes into Vault 👍

Not perfect yet: https://07840cc657b6cb5df66a-ca0266261d8d95f33f1974de7a62fd54.ssl.cf1.rackcdn.com/821732/3/check/nova-live-migration/8de2818/testr_results.html
So fasteners' inter process rw lock works, but we waste a lot of cpu time waiting for the write lock https://paste.opendev.org/show/811724/

fasteners unfortunately does not implement an inter process rw lock that could be configured to prefer writers over readers. And with the fcntl primitives I don't see how that would be possible to implement.

Still additional to the lock if we could also influence the order of the test execution in a way that serial tests are run at the end then we could avoid most of the wasted execution time we see in the current case.

The tempest CLI uses stestr internally to execute the tests. Stestr allows for grouping of the tests with --group-regex but uses an alphabetical ordering of the tests (if no timing data available)[1]. 

The unittest lib exposes some test case ordering configurable[2] but it does not seem to work together with stestr. At least in my trials I was able to hook into the unittest config but was not able to override the alphabetical ordering of stestr.

Also from my trials it is visible that the order of the tests in the file stestr uses via --load-list does not effect the order of the test execution.

So based on all this the best we can do is to influence the ordering by _naming_ the serial tests in a way that they end up at the end of the alphabetical list (assuming that tempest is always used in a clean stestr env where no timing data is available). 


[1] https://stestr.readthedocs.io/en/latest/MANUAL.html#test-scheduling
[2] https://docs.python.org/3/library/unittest.html#unittest.TestLoader.sortTestMethodsUsing
Done

The ordering forced by the name of the tests (zzz_serial) will not work in every case. It will only work when you run tempest for the first time. When you run it for the second time, then the stestr library uses run times of the tests (stored in the .stestr folder) to find the optimal order of the tests [1].

[1] https://stestr.readthedocs.io/en/latest/MANUAL.html?highlight=worker#test-scheduling

```
- worker:

  concurrency: 1

- worker:
  - [regex for tests we want to run in parallel]
```

Yeah worker files are not helping as the workers run in parallel.

I am taking a second look at this patch and I am thinking about two things:

1) I would change the "zzz_serial" to "serial"

2) Whether there is a way how to make the ordering more permanent (so the serial tests always run at the end). I think that if we merge the patch as it is right now, we will give up the scheduling feature of stestr which uses the logs from previous runs to optimize the usage of workers [1].

[1] https://stestr.readthedocs.io/en/latest/MANUAL.html#test-scheduling

I've tested the logic, it seems it's working as expected, we can also confirm that by checking the stackviz output (after the check jobs will be retriggered).

The zzz_serial tests are executed at the end even on a non-first tempest run. Therefore it doesn't affect stestr optimization very much (considering there will be just a handful of tests like this, which I believe is the case).

I made several suggestions to the documentation wording to make it more clear, readable and understandable to everyone reading that after we merge this.

> I am taking a second look at this patch and I am thinking about two things:
> 
> 1) I would change the "zzz_serial" to "serial"

We can, zzz is just an optimization to run the serial test at last (when tempest runs in a clean env like in the gate)

> 
> 2) Whether there is a way how to make the ordering more permanent (so the serial tests always run at the end). I think that if we merge the patch as it is right now, we will give up the scheduling feature of stestr which uses the logs from previous runs to optimize the usage of workers [1].

I don't think so. You mentioned previously that at the second run in the same env stestr will reorder the tests base on the logs of previous runs. So in a local env you keep the stestr optimization on and loose the serial optimization. In the gate we always run tempest in a clean env so there we never have stestr run optimization as there is no logs from previous run, in return we would have the serial optimization working.

I think this is a fair compromise to be able to test system level resources in tempest like host aggregates. I don't see much alternatives how to test them and keep running tempest in parallel.

> 
> [1] https://stestr.readthedocs.io/en/latest/MANUAL.html#test-scheduling

1) I think that we should name the folder "serial" instead o "zzz_serial" and place a comment here [1] to inform future maintainers that the "serial" folder should always be last in alphabetical order. There are only two root test folders in tempest "api" + "scenario" so the "serial" folder without the "zzz_" prefix would still be last in alphabetical order.

2) We should document more the reason why the tests are moved to the "serial" folder. I would add to each class that is moved to the "serial" folder a short comment explaining why it needs to be isolated from the rest of the tests. It might help future maintainers to decide whether a test can be removed from the "serial" folder if some circumstances in tempest change. And I would also update the documentation so that it explains the need to add a comment to the class when moving it to the "serial" folder.

/PATCHSET_LEVEL.message:
I probably did a poor job explaining why you'd want to use include_tasks.

Quick example;

 - name: "Bootstrap Keystone"
   import_tasks: bootstrap.yml
   when:
     - enable_keystone | bool
     - not skip_bootstrap | bool
     
if I set `skip_bootstrap=true`, first off the `Bootstrap keystone` is never displayed. Then you get a list of *all* the tasks within `bootstrap.yml` listed out as skipped. Roughly 20 tasks you'd never need to hear from.

If it were include_tasks, the output would just be

 TASK [Bootstrap Keystone] ***
 skipping: [bifrost]

If `skip_bootstrap=false`, you'd first get the printout `Bootstrap keystone` before the list of tasks from `bootstrap.yml`.

`import_tasks` doesn't display the `name` section.

I think you want to use include_tasks whenever you're applying a when condition.

include_tasks with a when condition will skip the whole file.

import_tasks with when will run all tasks inside the file with the when clause added.
Done
While it's not wrong, they will both work fine. I guarantee you'd want to use include_tasks if you ever looked at the output.
Done
I believe the import_tasks behavior is exactly what we want

I see what you mean now, I had another look at the docs as well after this explanation and I realized I got it wrong, thanks!
I'll change that
lgtm!

Well we're not removing caching entirely. We're just choosing to rely on the caching from importlib-metadata rather than rely on our own. No, is the answer.

The caching in stevedore is on-disk. It avoids having to scan the PYTHONPATH for all entry points. My understanding is that the caching in importlib.metadata is in memory. That won't help with CLI startup time.

stx-security-profiles-operator-helm/stx-.message:
This image is specified in a strange way (through env on line 17) and might not get picked up by the application framework.

Our application framework looks through helm charts and replaces image references with "registry.local:9001" instead of external registries like quay.io and gcr.io. It supports many formats of image references but I believe "env: value:" is not one of them. What likely happens is that the reference for external quay.io/gcr.io remains and the image is pulled from upstream instead of registry.local. The application framework will not download the image and push it to registry.local. This will fail on labs with no external access.

I believe we need to do something like this: https://opendev.org/starlingx/portieris-armada-app/commit/add76dfffb1f53701139dc55671bf38d945f38dd#diff-709166fcaed8cf330922106ca8772f930bacd770
In that change, line 12-16 is specified in a way the helm chart understands and can use. Notice how it refers to registry.local, which is a substitution normally made by the application framework, if it understands the image reference.
line 9-11 specifies an image for the application framework to download and push to registry.local.
In your case, your patch should refer to "registry.local:9001/gcr.io/..." instead of "gcr.io/..." and you should add an image reference for gcr.io/... to your static-overrides.yaml for the application framework

Hello Rodolfo, let me add Tyler. This one should be a complementary even with the work in progress on [1]. But let's double check with him.

About [1] It would be great if we could have a bit more details regarding performance improvement that this is going to give, since looks like we add complexity. I'm bit scary that some improvement in the current model would have fixed the problem with less complexity.

I'm apologies, I wanted to say Rodolfo... I will take care avoiding this misspelling

> e.g., Let's saw I am the admin and own network foo, which is not shared. All other networks in the cloud are also not shared. I then run 'osc network list --share' as the admin on the main branch: there are no results returned.

Thank you, this case can certainly be addressed with a minor change.

> Setting aside the functional changes, I have a rather complex test cloud loaded with many RBACs and projects in a use case that is unique to us - this PS results in a 90 sec runtime for 'osc network list --share' whereas main is 3.5 seconds.

It's an interesting point. The case with --share means we have to scan the whole rbacs list, right? It's true that my proposal would not bring any improvement. Could you explain (if you have a moment) how your solution is helping us for both cases (with and without --share)?

I'm not a DBA (nor a lawyer!) -- but I think the large win from my PS comes from the elimination of the outer join between RBACs and objects such as networks. With an outer join, the result created is often large and I think it prevents indexes from being used under certain circumstances, which results in table scans across large anonymous inner queries -- where the outer join is usually present.

So, in the case of needing to determine which networks are shared, the filter being applied in this context for my PS is going only against RBACs and NOT objects which don't have them (again, as there is no outer join). Moreover, as the filter is directly against the RBACs, indexes such as 'rbacs.action' can be leveraged to avoid a scan.

Hi Rodrigo

Thanks for this change - looks to address the challenge of only the lead unit presenting data to consuming applications appropriately, providing an eventually consistent set of data presentation from all vault units.

I have one concern that I think we need to consider changing approach for; you're using leader storage which has one behaviour consideration that we might want to avoid.

When a leader calls leader-set, leader-settings-changed will immediately execute on all follower units - for an existing larger deployment this will create a large number of incremental hook executions as the followers then re-echo the cached data to consuming applications on certificate at a time.

The other consideration is that leader storage is eventually going to disappear, being replaced by the application data bag on a peer relation.

The charm already as a peer relation - if we used the application data bag on this relational rather than leader storage then the charm upgrade for and existing deployment will have a lot less hook executions - data is only committed to the model at the end of the upgrade-charm hook rather than on every leader-set call as with leader storage.

@tinwood @gnuoy - I'd appreciate your thoughts on this change in approach.
WIP

@jamespage: Thanks for your review! So if leader-set is going away, then I think there is only one way forward. The cascading hook executions is great observation, and it will be a nice performance bonus from changing the approach, thank you!

I will abandon this patch and starting working on a new one from scratch using the application data bag.
I think it would be acceptable to adapt this review to use peer application data storage - the primitives as much the same and this is pretty close.
I expect this patch to fail, see https://review.opendev.org/c/openstack/charm-vault/+/866077

src/reactive/vault_handlers.py.message:
I added this to address the CI issue but I don't feel very good good about it.

Basically the issue is that this method gets run first when leader-settings changed is triggered on the non-leader peers after running the upload_csr action. The get_chain() method below fails with 500 error "unable to parse CA", as I suppose the updated CSR/CA hasn't been written yet in the non-leader peers, at the time this method is running. 

By not running this method on leadership.changed, we avoid the issue, and this method will be run as part of another hook as soon as the leadership.changed flag is cleared. We will have a small gap where data is not consistent, or hook errors could prevent the data from being propagated.

Other alternatives that might be better:

1) If we could reorder the method execution so this runs last, it could potentially address the problem cleanly

2) I feel that running this method manually at the end of assess_status is better than this because it introduces some ordering. I obtained similar results in my testing, but then the code is no longer "reactive". In my testing I also needed to skip execution when the leadership.changed flag is set, as it seems (need to double check) that the hook that sets the CA/CSR needs to end successfully to write the CA, before it can be read (or maybe the assess_status method is also running before the CA/CSR is set).

3) Alternatively we could just skip the method when the CA cannot be obtained. It will avoid the issue as well and not worry about the ordering. This, however, feels like masking other potential problems we don't know about, could introduce a new silent bug and we may not notice the certs are inconsistent and the changes have not been propagated.
